Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Hello Abhishek,

We need to come up with a better idea than hardcoding configurable names (obmc-console.guests) into bmcweb. In my view the socket name should be an implementation detail between obmc-console-server and obmc-console-client.

This may take the form of adding some DBus support to obmc-console and providing an interface to acquire a connected socket e.g. via a method call.

Adding Jeremy to get his thoughts.

Abandoned

No progress in the last 6 months.
Can we just call this hypervisor everywhere?
Done
Done

This is defined here by the socket-id 
https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/search?q=guests&type=

I think we should update this to be hypervisor or something others can match
let's wait for that then
Done
Remove one of these
Done
This seems like a not-descriptive-enough url, considering this is something different?
hypervisor?
Done
My review from the earlier patchset still stands.
ACK Sorry I miss that
I still need to address this comment but can we do that in separate pr
so this can go in

This whole file is copied and pasted from obmc_console.hpp, then the namespace changed.  Please don't duplicate code in this way;  Abstract it into common classes and methods, and invoke them with the appropriate arguments where required.
Comment seems to have been ignored.  At least an ACK if you understand it would be appreciated, so maintainers can know that you're working on it.
Done
I see no mention of this anywhere in the project.  Maybe I'm missing something?

As is, I think this just seems very IBM-specific. Really what you want is support for an arbitrary number of consoles in bmcweb right? I don't see why the functionality should mention things like "hypervisor".
+1. It would be better to separate it into two patches, one for the mutliple console backend support (the console websocket class), another for the hypervisor console implementation.
I suspect we don't need a global scoped shared_ptr.  If this is global scope, there's no need to share ownership in the way you've used it.
I suggest using the full `consoleWebSocket` as the name as cons can stand for many things like connections.
Done
Please put this abstracting the websocket class into its own patch, then we can add the hypervisor stuff as a subsequent patch.
looks like a typo?  not sure what "hyep" is.
Done
This is going to add this hypervisor route for all systems, including systems that don't have a hypervisor.  I'm fairly certain that's not what you intended.

"console1" is not specific enough of a URI for this use case, there are lots of consoles, if we're creating a whole new section of code, it needs to be in a new name, although I suspect we need to come up with a naming policy, which we can work through when your patch is split up.
that we can handle using yocto build process.
This logic looks incorrect  addConnection() needs to be called in both cases.  As-written, I'm not sure how this passed any testing, maybe there's a subtle race?
It works, but let me restructure the code to make it easy to read and understand.
This doesn't look needed?  conn is used on line 37.
Please handle the "if (hyepWebsocket == nullptr)" in its own branch, and if that happens, we should be logging an internal error.
This is a bug.  If multiple clients are connected, this will close the unix socket when the first one disconnects.
The naming should be more specific I think, there are other services using Websocket in bmcweb like KVM, virtual media.
Please mark this class with the final specifier.
Done
In modern code, please accept these kinds of things by string_view.
Doesn't need inline when it's part of a class.  This is true for the rest of these implementations below.  Please fix all of them.
Done
Done

Now that this is generic, and now that obmc-console supports multiple client I suspect this pattern doesn't hold as well anymore.  Should we have a unix socket per websocket, which moves a lot of the complexity of managing buffers into obmc-console, where it arguably should belong?
this-> is redundant.
Done
Why is this a unique_ptr?  It seems like it should be taken by value?
Done

I suspect we need to rethink how these options are done, given that there's untold reasons that people would need a serial port, and having a configure option for each possible use case is going to lead to a lot of complexity.
